climbs.name: At the Hundredth Meridian
climbs.fa: Greg Hughes and Michel Martin, Sept. 2020

content.description:
Enjoyable movement, bolts when you need them, gear that will make you think. Clip the right most bolt of the anchor then move up and right to a bolt on the face. Continue up on large features/flakes to a reddish colored face protecting with natural gear as you make your way toward the steepening bolted face. Work through the tricky crux then pull onto the slab above plugging a few more pieces before topping out.



This route is on the face directly right of the corner that is Tercel Tower. The start is just right of the bolted anchor. 

4 bolts, stand rack, tree anchor with chain.

Fun climbing leads up to the base of the overhanging offwidth. Use either offwidth technique or small features left and right of the crack. A number 5 camalot is necessary to protect the crux moves.



The start is directly below the overhanging corner. Begin in a crack just up and right of a bolted anchor. 

Single rack to 5. Tree anchor. Rap the route.

This wall is easily spotted from the parking area or the farmers field. Tercel Tower is the obvious overhanging corner in the middle of the wall. The rock quality on this wall is not the best in places but there are still some worthwhile routes. It's south facing position means it gets almost all day sun and would be a good place to go on cooler days that have sunshine.
